Based on the last few centuries of data for atmospheric CO2 from the Law Dome ice core data and the Keeling curve (CO2), the CDIAC’s historical record of fossil-fuel CO2 Emissions (ECO2), the Arrhenius logarithmic law relating atmospheric CO2 to its radiative forcing (RF = log2(CO2), reconstructed total solar irradiance (TSI), and the historical records of surface temperature on land and sea (HadCRUT4), all averaged over 63 years, I would say yes beyond a reasonable doubt. Does CO2 come from ECO2? Since 1750, XCO2, the excess of CO2 over its preindustrial level of 280 ppm, has been rising at 2% a year and has closely tracked 40% of ECO2 throughout.For an analogy, suppose you are blindfolded and you pour water into a leaky drum at a rate increasing by 2% a minute, and the amount in the drum rises at a rate also increasing by 2% a minute, yet at any time only 40% of what you’ve poured remains in the drum. After a while you become convinced that 60% of the incoming water must be leaking out leaving 40% in the drum.I would say that, beyond a reasonable doubt, this proves that the water in the bucket came from what was poured in. Maybe some natural source is also adding water, but it would have to increase at a rate exactly matching the increasing rate you have been pouring it in. What are the odds there would be such a natural source?Replacing water-in by ECO2, water-remaining by XCO2, and “minute” by “year”, this exactly describes what is happening with emitted CO2 and retained XCO2. I would say that, beyond a reasonable doubt, this proves that the excess CO2 in the atmosphere came from what was emitted.Does HadCRUT4 follow the combination of TSI and RF = log(CO2), in some proportion or other? When all three are smoothed with a 63-year running mean and the last two are fitted to the first using multiple regression, the standard deviation of the residual is 5 millikelvin (mK). Leaving out TSI worsens the fit to 15 mK while leaving out RF and just using TSI gives a fit of 35 mK, as per the following figure. Fitting just RF (= log2(CO2)) yields a model that curves up, projecting a rise in 63-year climate that is 2.66 °C higher than today (2016) assuming XCO2 continues to rise at 2% a year. Fitting just TSI is no fit at all because TSI rose in the first half of the century but not the second half, unlike HadCRUT4. Fitting both together however gives a very good fit. This shows two things: (a) RF alone doesn’t explain rising HadCRUT4, and (b) RF and TSI together does an excellent job of explaining the coarser or more slowly changing aspects of global climate. In particular global surface temperature averaged over the 63 years 2069–2131 (the meaning of 63-year climate in 2100) is likely to be 1.90 °C higher than today if XCO2 continues to rise at 2% a year, the rate it’s been growing for centuries now. That plus an approximate 1 °C rise since CO2 was at its preindustrial level of 280 ppm (RF = 8.13) comes to a total rise of almost 3 °C during the industrial era up to 2100. I suspect that 1.56 °C is below the true climate sensitivity (CS) because 63-year TSI is a bit distorted, and that a 21-year filter will raise this CS to more like 1.8, though not as high as the 2.19 °C obtained when TSI is omitted from the model obtained by fitting 63-year data. [EDIT: I appended the following to the original comment, and also changed AtCO2 to CO2, plus more minor edits.] CS as defined here is simply the coefficient of RF = log2(CO2). It is similar to the IPCC’s Transient Climate Response, which models CO2 as growing at 1% a year. If instead CO2 is modeled as 280 + XCO2 with XCO2 growing at 2% a year a much better fit is obtained to the IPCC’s Representative Concentration Pathway 8.5 (RCP8.5) as per this figure.  Except for the period 2030–2090, where the XCO2-based model drops a bit below RCP8.5 before returning at 2090, the two are essentially interchangeable. I prefer the former because it is a simpler encoding of RCP8.5 where it is known, and who knows what CO2 will be in 2060? I suggest calling the XCO2-based model the Hofmann model, since it is essentially the one David Hofmann proposed in 2010. As an alternative to Transient Climate Response in modeling I suggest the term Prevailing Climate Response for climate sensitivity estimated based on the Hofmann model instead of TCR’s 1%-a-year model. Now if you invest $1 at 2%, in 242 years you will have 1.02^242 = $120.57. By the same token if XCO2 in the model is 1 ppm in 1772, then the model says that 242 years later, i.e. in 2014, XCO2 will be 120.57 for a total CO2 of 400.57 ppm, within 1 ppm where it actually was that year. And if CO2 continues on that 242-year-old trajectory, by 2100 it will have reached 942 ppm. (The RCP8.5 pathway has 936 ppm for that year and 945 for 2101, i.e. essentially the same.) If for any reason it doesn’t reach it then of course it could end up either higher or lower, we’re only saying if. Methane in melting tundra swamps might drive it higher, decarbonization might drive it lower, both might happen and cancel each other out, no one can say for sure. But no one can say it won’t continue along its present path either.

Let’s take a look at the meaning of the word proof. Definition of proof 1a : the cogency of evidence that compels acceptance by the mind of a truth or a fact b : the process or an instance of establishing the validity of a statement especially by derivation from other statements in accordance with principles of reasoning 2 obsolete : experience 3 : something that induces certainty or establishes validity More at: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/proof The definitions relating to your question are numbers 1a and 3. By definition 1a, man-made climate change has already been proved. By definition 3 “establishes validity”, man-made climate change has already been proved. The “or” between the statements means that only one of the conditions must be met, and validity has been established so again man-made climate changed has been proved. So when “skeptics” demand proof, they are focusing on the certainty in the definition. But when it comes to scientific theories, certainty can never be a requirement for scientific theories because theories can and do change. Newton’s Theory of Gravity was modified by Einstein’s. Newton’s theory had problems (orbit of Mercury) but it was accepted even without certainty. Einstein’s theory has problems (black holes) but is accepted. The Standard Model of Particle Physics has many problems (dark matter, for one) but is accepted. By demanding certainty, the “skeptics” are demanding more than the definition of theories requires. The purpose of demanding certainty is to create unreasonable doubt. For more information on this tactic, I suggest googling “Merchants of Doubt”. “A scientific theory is a well-substantiated explanation of some aspect of the natural world, based on a body of facts that have been repeatedly confirmed through observation and experiment.” https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_theory

You can’t “prove” scientific theories in the same sense as you can “prove” mathematical statements. Newton didn’t and couldn’t prove his laws of motion are correct, any more than we can prove Special Relativity is correct. But there is a secondary meaning of “prove”, which means to “test”. This is the meaning in science. Hence expressions like “proving ground” (for testing ground), “the proof of the the pudding is in the eating” (the test of a good pudding is how good it tastes), and a few others. So man-made global warming can be “proved” (tested) through normal scientific methods, such as seeing how well climate models which assume a man-made component accurately predict future climate.

Yes man made activities are largely responsible for global warming such as: Burning Fossil Fuels: burning coal to generate electricity, burning oil to power vehicles and aircraft (vehicle emissions), or burning wood in fires used for cooking or to provide heat, etc. changes the state of stored organic carbon from a liquid (e.g. oil) or solid (e.g. coal/wood) into a gas (carbon dioxide) which is released into the atmosphere. Deforestation: vegetation absorbs carbon dioxide from the atmosphere during the process of photosynthesis, converting this to carbon which is stored within all plants (i.e it is a carbon sink). When vegetation is burned, this organic carbon is released into the atmosphere in the form of carbon dioxide, and in so doing becomes a carbon source rather than a carbon sink. Decomposing organic matter: landfills, animal waste, sewerage and dams are all human sources of methane. For example, organic matter is trapped behind dam walls where it sinks to the bottom of the dam and decomposes. Bacteria produce methane in the decomposition process, which slowly escapes to the surface and is released into the atmosphere. Landfill gas operations and biodigesters provide a method of mitigation, and not only harness methane that would otherwise be released into the atmosphere, but also provide an alternative source of fuel. Natural gas extraction: methane escapes during oil and gas extraction (e.g. fracking) operations and is released into the atmosphere. Fertilizers: Nitrous oxide is a potent greenhouse gas that is released primarily by fertilizers used in agriculture and landscaping, but also during the burning of fossil fuels and other organic matter. Atmospheric nitrous oxide levels have risen by roughly 18% since the Industrial Revolution, spiking rapidly towards the end of the 1900’s. Industrial appliances: Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) are long-lasting greenhouse gases that also destroy the ozone layer. CFCs do not occur naturally in the atmosphere – they are synthetic compounds that only originate from human sources, including: aerosols, foaming agents, refrigerants, and other industrial applications.
